content.description: Begin down in the hole on the left. climb up and out of the hole using the long solution pockets.  Throw out and right to move into the right groove, throw from there to the lip and top out.  An absolute classic, one of the best on the mountain.
content.protection: Climbs over a flat rock that matches the countour of the cave, so its easy to pad.

content.description: SDS on the obvious large flake feature. Pull up into the glued horn and work right onto the face. Pull off a few very balancy moves, involving a sharp crimp/gaston, and throw for the flat jug near the top.
content.protection: One-two pads and maybe a spotter. Great problem to work if you are alone - very low consequence fall/landing zone.
content.location: Below (downhill from the Bat Cave), through the tunnel/rock pile. West face of the boulder faces the Orange Ripple Boulder.

content.description: Climbs the left runnel in the bat cave. Start down low in the hole. Make a few moves to establish in the runnel and then exit straight up on good holds.
content.location: Left side of the bat cave.

content.description: Begin with a sit start on the steep right side of the north face.  Climb up using crimps and slopers to the point and rock up onto the face.  Continue up and left across a difficult gaston to top out by the little tree.

SDS on good sidepulls. Work up the the triangular feature to the  hollow hold >(suspect)< and throw for the pancake-like flake, move right to another flake and finish up the arete (tends to be dirty).
content.protection: Can be padded easily - One rock (grounded) right in the middle of the landing so two (or more) regular pads (as well as spotters)  should do it.
content.location: Instead of turning West (left) to go to the Bat Cave off the main trail keep walking straight North (trail is a bit overgrown) downhill 20 yards or so, and then West about 20 feet is the boulder. The climbable face is East facing and very bright (hard to miss).
